div.p: A ſhort ANSVVER OF IOHN LING, To the 16. Quaeres of Ioſeph Heming, about CHRISTMAS.
Wherein all the care that can be is taken to avoyd expence of paper, ſo much having beene ſpoyled already. For

q.l: Wer't not for Chriſtmas which is nigh,
When fruit, ſpice, eaten and digeſted Pie
Calls for more paper, no man could make ſhift
How to employ JOS. HEMING to his thrift.

div.p: Printed in the Yeare 1648.

div.head: A ſhort Anſwer of Iohn Ling to the 16. Quaeres of Ioſeph Heming about Chriſtmas.
div.p: IT is perceived that one Joſeph Heming, not long before Chriſtmas, 1648. (as by his printed Paper doth appeare) from his Study in Ʋttoxeter, otherwiſe and vulgarly Ʋxter, in the ſayd yeare doth challenge all thoſe who can write and reade, to anſwer his 16. Quaeries concerning the obſervation of the Feaſt of Chriſtmas, or the Nativity of our Lord and Saviour Jeſus Chriſt; to which I John Ling having been a Grammer Schollar, and having ſeene ſomewhat in the world both in this Church, and the Reformed beyond Sea, doe make this Anſwer.

div.head: The firſt Quaere.

q.hi: Whether ſuch religious cuſtomes as are binding to all the Churches of Ieſus Chriſt, ought not to have ſure footing upon the Word of God, or Apoſtolicall practice?

div.p: Resp. Becauſe I will not make Paper deare by long Anſwers or Recitalls, I ſay ſuch Religious Cuſtomes as are binding to all the Churches of Jeſus Chriſt, ought to have footing upon the word of God, or Apoſtolicall practice.

div.head: The ſecond Quaere.

p.q: Whether you can ſubſtantially prove that Chriſt was borne on the 25 of December? And what your proofes are?

div.p: Resp. It is not materiall, I, or no, whether I can prove that Chriſt was borne on the 25 of December, as it now ſtandeth in the Engliſh Calendar.

div.head: The third Quaere.

q.hi: Whether the celebration of that day (grant he was borne on it) can be clearely warranted by you from Scripture? And what your Scriptures are?

div.p: Resp. It imports no more then what is anſwered in the firſt and ſecond.

div.head: The fourth Quaere.

p.q: Whether you can cleare it by ſound conſequence from the New Teſtament, though not ſet downe there in totidem verbis?

div.p: Resp. It is cleared by ſound conſequence, both from the Old and New Teſtament, that the day of the Birth of our Saviour, God and man, ſhould be kept with Feſtivity: I will now firſt give you inſtance in the Angels ſong to the Shepheards, Glory be to God on high, on earth peace, good will towards men, ſee the 118 Pſalme, 22.23. and 24. verſes, The ſtone which the builders refuſed is the head of the corner, which is interpreted in the New Teſtament to be meant of Chriſt. 24. This is the day which the Lord hath made, wee will rejoyce and be glad in it, which all good Interpreters ſay to be meant by the day of the Birth of our Lord and Saviour Jeſus Chriſt. Many places there are in Iſaiah, and other of the Prophets: So that now you have better proofes from Scripture for keeping holy an Anniverſary day for the celebration of the Birth of our Lord, then for changing the Sabbath to the Lords day; the proofes whereof are chiefely grounded upon Apoſtolicall Cuſtome, Iſaiah, 28.16. Math. 21.42. Acts, 4.11. Rom. 9.33. 1. Peter, 2.6. and 7.

div.head: The fifth Quaere.

q.hi: Whether you can doe it by univerſall tradition?

div.p: Resp. Its done by Univerſall Tradition, and in that I will bring it to the Cuſtomary Practice of the Reformed Churches of Dutch▪ French, and Geneva.

div.head: The ſixt Quaere.

p.q: Whether (in caſe it can be evidenced by none of theſe, viz. plaine Text, ſollid Inference, univerſall Tradition) it be not a meere humane invention, and ſo Will worſhip? And how you will one day acquit your ſelves before God, for placing, and crying up mens Inventions, inſtead of the inſtitutions of Ieſus Chriſt? And whether it were not faithfull dealing with poore ſimple people to tell them that you have neither of theſe to warrant it?

div.p: Reſp. I anſwer, it were falſe dealing to tell Chriſtian People that which were untrue.

div.head: The ſeaventh Quaere.

q.hi: (Since dayes and times commanded by God himſelfe to be obſerved under the Law, were, and are unlawfull under the Goſpel) Whether dayes and times commanded by men, and not by God, under the Goſpell, are not leſſe lawfull?

div.p: Reſp. If this day and time were onely commanded by men, it were unlawfull, ſo far as to command it as a meere Religious duty.

div.head: The eighth Quaere.

p.q: Whether the true and genuine Interpretation of Chriſtmas be Chriſt man? And whether to perſwade people 'tis ſo, be not to abuſe and delude them? And whether we may not as well interpret Candlemas Candleman, Michaelmas Michaelman, as Chriſtmas Chriſtman?

div.p:
Reſp. (Becauſe you make ſport, and have brought in a Gamboll)
That I have a conjecture that Joſeph Heming is ſome Schoole Maſter, or ſome great Schoole Boy, that can interpret the Latine Mas for a man, and then Chriſtmas is Chriſtman; and certainely it is to abuſe people to perſwade them ſo and ſo of the reſt: But I have heard what was anſwered Dr. Lambe by a good fellow, to whom he objected to have ſayd Chriſtyde, and why not as well Tom tyde? The Anſwer was he could ſay Chriſtmas, or Thomas, or Lambe, aſſe, and ſo he left him, and ſo doe I you with your Gamboll.

div.head: The ninth Quaere.

p.q: Whether the Saints are bound to rejoyce in the Birth of Chriſt on that day men ſuperſtitiouſly call Chriſtmas, more then at other times? And whether the Lords day be not [the] day appoynted for them to rejoyce on?

div.p: Reſp. You begge the Queſtion of Superſtition, and ſo untill you frame the Argument out of the Queſtion in Moode and Figure, I ſhall anſwer you no more upon that poynt.

div.head: The tenth Quaere.

p.q: Whether Chriſtmas day ought in any reſpect to be eſteemed above another of the Weeke dayes? And whether people may not without offence to God follow their lawfull vocations on that day?

div.p: Reſp. That by the eſtabliſhed Lawes of this Kingdome, in the times of the firſt Reformation (and ſtill continued) this is commanded to be kept as a holy day.

div.head: The eleaventh Quaere.

q.hi: Whether you thinke the Parliament and Aſſembly have erred and played the fooles in condemning and raſing out Holy dayes not warranted in the Word? And whether to obſerve them, be not highly to diſlike, and flatly to contradict (in poynt of practice at leaſt) their proceedings in order to a Reformation?

div.p: Resp. I ſay it is a Propoſition of ill language, and therefore I ſay no more, but demand of you whether you thinke the firſt Reformers that ſuffered Martyrdome were Fooles and Knaves?

div.head: The twelfth Quaere.

p.q: Whether (ſince moſt men and women in England doe blindely and ſuperstitiouſly beleeve Chriſt was borne that day) preaching on it, doth not nouriſh and ſtrengthen them in that beliefe?

div.p: Reſp. At firſt you begge the Queſtion, but to the ſecond part of it; I ſay ſince preaching is lawfull upon any day; ſo is it expedient, if not neceſſary upon a day commanded.

div.head: The thirteenth Quaere.

p.q: Whether this Feaſt had not its riſe and growth from Chriſtians conformity to the mad Feaſts Saturnalia (kept in December to Saturne the Father of Gods) in which there was a Sheafe offered to Ceres Goddeſſe of Corne, a hymne in her praiſe called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ? And whether thoſe Chriſtians by name, to cloake it, did not afterwards call it Yule; and Chriſtmas (as though it were for Chriſts honour?) And whether it be not yet by ſome (more ancient then truely or knowingly religious) called Yule, and the mad playes (wherewith 'tis celebrated like thoſe Saturnalia) Yule games? And whether from the offering of that Sheafe to Ceres; from that ſong in her praiſe: from thoſe gifts the Heathens gave their friends in the Calends of January, ominis gratia; did not ariſe or ſpring our blazes; Chriſtmas Kariles, and New yeares gifts?

div.p:
Resp. Whether this Feaſt had not its Rice from Chriſtians conformity to the mad Feaſt Saturnalia, I anſwer, I thinke it a very mad Queſtion: But I confeſſe in ſome Nations they call that Feaſt Yule, and amongſt your brethren the Scots, they call it Zule, as I have found it in their Callenders; but untill you can prove that thoſe Nations
ſpeake Greeke, you will be far to ſeeke for your Argument: Therefore good Mr. Schoolemaſter, or Schooleboy, leave off your Etymologies; for you will finde it hard to prove that Chriſtians uſed to celebrate this Feaſt in any relation to the Saturnalia or Ceres Songs.

div.head: The fourteenth Quaere.

q.hi: Whether conformity to, and retention of Heatheniſh Cuſtomes be commendable in Chriſtians, ſutable or agreeable with Goſpel Principles, though under pretext of Chriſts Honour and Worſhip?

div.p: Resp. In the Negative it is not lawfull; but how will you apply it, John Ellis, I cry you mercy Joſeph Heming?

div.head: The fifteenth Quaere.

q.hi: Whether you are not bound to prove your practice for the conviction and ſatisfaction of your Brethren, whoſe duty it is to walke with you in things agreeable to the minde of Chriſt? And in caſe you cannot; Whether you ought not to acknowledge your errour, lay downe your practice (as others have done theirs) no longer befooling and miſleading the people committed to your charge?

div.p: I anſwer, this reproofe would ſerve for a Preacher if he had miſled his people, of which number I am not, but if this charge be unjuſt, ſee how you diſobey the Lawes of God and man.

div.head: The ſixteenth Quaere.

q.hi: Whether in caſe you returne no Anſwer to theſe Quaeries, I have not ground ſufficient to conclude you utterly unable to give any rationall account of your practice, now put upon it?

div.p: Resp. Whether I have anſwered your Quaeries or no; Let me know it by your confeſſion or Reply.
